term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.
Record details about an anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Relative location medial to the landmark.
Relative location lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior to the landmark.
In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.
Relative location anterior to the landmark.
Relative location posterior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.
In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Ordinal position 1 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 2 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 3 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 4 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 5 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 6 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 7 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 8 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 9 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 10 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 11 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 12 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 13 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 14 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 15 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 16 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 17 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 18 of an anatomical location.
Image or images used to identify a location.
Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.
Record details about an anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Relative location medial to the landmark.
Relative location lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior to the landmark.
In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.
Relative location anterior to the landmark.
Relative location posterior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.
In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Ordinal position 1 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 2 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 3 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 4 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 5 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 6 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 7 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 8 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 9 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 10 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 11 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 12 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 13 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 14 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 15 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 16 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 17 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 18 of an anatomical location.
Image or images used to identify a location.
Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.
To record the phycial properties of an object such as a body part, specimen or lesion.

A text description of other physical characteristics of the object. Do not use to record characteristics that might affect the quality of a test interpretation - use 'Specimen received issues' in the Specimen archetype for this purpose.
The object concerned. May be a body part, device or specimen.
Details of a specimen container. This is often integral to workflow and reporting of pathology specimens, particularly antamical and histological pathology specimens.
Identifier of the place from where the container should be collected.
The unique identifier given to the container. May be multiple.
A text description of the container.
Details of a sub-components which comprises the container (e.g., description of the slide and of the coverslip)
A description of the component material.
The data and time that the specimen was uplifted for transportation to the laboratory.
Identifier of person or agency responsible for transporting the container to the lab.
To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy. resection.

Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
Any special preservative or transport medium requirements.
Dimensions / weight of sample. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
The date and time that the specimen was processed by the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An incorrect preservative was used when transporting the specimen.
An insufficient sample was given to undertake measurement.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result data.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Details of the needle used to take a needle biopsy.
The diameter of the core obtained via needle biopsy expressed using the needle gauge used to take the specimen.
The length of the core obtained by needle biopsy.
The number of needle biopsy cores received.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Details of container and transport details used.
Any conditions associated with handling the specimen in-transit e.g 'Keep refrigerated'.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
The date and time after which the specimen can no longer be used for testing.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to finish place or has finished.
The broad category of diagnostic service to which the requested test belongs.
The identfier of the unit providing the test.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Generic request for a laboratory request.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
The preferred date and time by which the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request including clinical context.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.

Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result data.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Details of the needle used to take a needle biopsy.
The diameter of the core obtained via needle biopsy expressed using the needle gauge used to take the specimen.
The length of the core obtained by needle biopsy.
The number of needle biopsy cores received.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Details of container and transport details used.
Any conditions associated with handling the specimen in-transit e.g 'Keep refrigerated'.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
The date and time after which the specimen can no longer be used for testing.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to finish place or has finished.
Details about contact person within organisation
Name of a person to contact at the organisation.
Details about contact person within organisation
Name of a person to contact at the organisation.
Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.

Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.
Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.

Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the pathology test result as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Actual value of the result. Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts, free text, or multimedia images.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.

A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.

Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.
Details about the individual specimen to which these Result group test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Overall test result status.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.
The date that the analysis was performed.
Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.
The status of the result value.
Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Result status.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release
The specimen has been sent to the laboratory.
Some but not all technical results are available at the lab.
Some but not all clinical results are available at the lab.
The results have been validated by the requesting clinician.
The specimen has been received and processing has been scheduled.
Identifier of the specimen collection appointment.
Order message has been sent to lab.
Transport of the specimen to the laboratory has been scheduled.
The test was aborted by the laboratory.
Actions arising based on a laboratory request
Actions arising from a laboratory specimen request.
The lab request has been postponed but will be organised in the future
An appointment for the specimen collection has been arranged
The speciment for this lab request has been collected
The specimen of this lab request has been sent out or received by the laboratory
All tests has been completed at the lab, but not clinically reported.
The laboratory action related to the laboratory request is completed and report processed
All test results have been clinically reported at the lab.
The investigator has established that further laboratory request is required
The person did not attend for their appointment
The lab test has not been implemented, but no further contact with the laboratory
The person did not attend on multiple occasions - no further appointments will been sent
Lab test has been aborted because of inappropriate specimen
The name of the test that was ordered.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The identifier of the person placing the request.
The identifier of the organisation to whom the request has been made.
The report is incomplete. Further updates should be expected.
The final version of the report. Further updates are not anticipated.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.

items.items: The report is incomplete. Further updates should be expected.
The final version of the report. Further updates are not anticipated.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
*The report is incomplete. Further updates should be expected.(en)
*The final version of the report. Further updates are not anticipated.(en)
*Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.(en)
*Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.(en)
*Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
The broad category of diagnostic service to which the requested test belongs.
The identfier of the unit providing the test.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Generic request for a laboratory request.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
The preferred date and time by which the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request including clinical context.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
*The broad category of diagnostic service to which the requested test belongs.(en)
*The identfier of the unit providing the test.(en)
*Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.(en)
*The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.(en)
*The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.(en)
*The preferred date and time by which the service should be performed or completed.(en)
*A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.(en)
*A narrative description explaining the reason for request including clinical context.(en)
*Stated intent of the request by the referrer.(en)
*True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.(en)
*Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.(en)
*Local detailed information such as billing requirements.(en)
*Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.(en)
*Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.(en)

*The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.(en)
*A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.(en)
*Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.(en)
*A detailed narrative description of the service requested.(en)
*Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.(en)
*Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.(en)
*The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.(en)
*The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.(en)
To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy. resection.

Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
Any special preservative or transport medium requirements.
Dimensions / weight of sample. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
The date and time that the specimen was processed by the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An incorrect preservative was used when transporting the specimen.
An insufficient sample was given to undertake measurement.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result data.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Details of the needle used to take a needle biopsy.
The diameter of the core obtained via needle biopsy expressed using the needle gauge used to take the specimen.
The length of the core obtained by needle biopsy.
The number of needle biopsy cores received.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Details of container and transport details used.
Any conditions associated with handling the specimen in-transit e.g 'Keep refrigerated'.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
The date and time after which the specimen can no longer be used for testing.
The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to finish place or has finished.
*To record details of a laboratory specimen.(en)
*Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.(en)
*Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.(en)
*Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.(en)
*The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy. resection.(en)

*Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.(en)
*The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.(en)
*Any special preservative or transport medium requirements.(en)
*Dimensions / weight of sample. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles (en)
*The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy. (en)
*The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.(en)
*The date and time that the specimen was processed by the laboratory.(en)
*Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.(en)
*An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.(en)
*An incorrect preservative was used when transporting the specimen.(en)
*An insufficient sample was given to undertake measurement.(en)
*An error arose when handling the specimen.(en)
*The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.(en)
*An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.(en)
*The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.(en)
*The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.(en)
*The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.(en)
*The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.(en)

*This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result data.(en)

*Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.(en)
*The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.(en)
*Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.(en)
*The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.(en)
*Details of the needle used to take a needle biopsy.(en)
*The diameter of the core obtained via needle biopsy expressed using the needle gauge used to take the specimen.(en)
*The length of the core obtained by needle biopsy.(en)
*The number of needle biopsy cores received.(en)
*Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.(en)
*The total number of containers holding this specimen.(en)
*Details of container and transport details used.(en)
*Any conditions associated with handling the specimen in-transit e.g 'Keep refrigerated'.(en)
*The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.(en)
*The date and time after which the specimen can no longer be used for testing.(en)
*The date and time at which the collection has been ordered to finish place or has finished.(en)
Record details about an anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Relative location medial to the landmark.
Relative location lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior to the landmark.
In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.
Relative location anterior to the landmark.
Relative location posterior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.
In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Ordinal position 1 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 2 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 3 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 4 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 5 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 6 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 7 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 8 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 9 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 10 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 11 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 12 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 13 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 14 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 15 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 16 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 17 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 18 of an anatomical location.
Image or images used to identify a location.
Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.
Anatomski opis lokacije na telesu oz. pozicije telesa
Tona anatomska lokacija / toka /predel na telesu
*Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.(en)
*In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.(en)
*Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.(en)
*Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.(en)
*Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.(en)
*Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.(en)

*Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.(en)
*Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.(en)
*Distance of location from the identified landmark.(en)
*Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.(en)
*In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.(en)
*In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.(en)
*In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.(en)
*Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.(en)
*Image or images used to identify a location.(en)
*Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.(en)
To record the phycial properties of an object such as a body part, specimen or lesion.

A text description of other physical characteristics of the object. Do not use to record characteristics that might affect the quality of a test interpretation - use 'Specimen received issues' in the Specimen archetype for this purpose.
The object concerned. May be a body part, device or specimen.
*To record the phycial properties of an object such as a body part, specimen or lesion.(en)

*A text description of other physical characteristics of the object. Do not use to record characteristics that might affect the quality of a test interpretation - use 'Specimen received issues' in the Specimen archetype for this purpose.(en)
*The object concerned. May be a body part, device or specimen.(en)
Details of a specimen container. This is often integral to workflow and reporting of pathology specimens, particularly antamical and histological pathology specimens.
Identifier of the place from where the container should be collected.
The unique identifier given to the container. May be multiple.
A text description of the container.
Details of a sub-components which comprises the container (e.g., description of the slide and of the coverslip)
A description of the component material.
The data and time that the specimen was uplifted for transportation to the laboratory.
Identifier of person or agency responsible for transporting the container to the lab.
*Details of a specimen container. This is often integral to workflow and reporting of pathology specimens, particularly antamical and histological pathology specimens.(en)
*Identifier of the place from where the container should be collected.(en)
*The unique identifier given to the container. May be multiple.(en)
*Details of a sub-components which comprises the container (e.g., description of the slide and of the coverslip)(en)
*The data and time that the specimen was uplifted for transportation to the laboratory.(en)
*Identifier of person or agency responsible for transporting the container to the lab.(en)
Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.

Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.
Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.

Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the pathology test result as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Actual value of the result. Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts, free text, or multimedia images.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.

A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.

Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.
Details about the individual specimen to which these Result group test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Overall test result status.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.
The date that the analysis was performed.
Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.
The status of the result value.
Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Result status.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release
*Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.(en)

*Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.(en)
*Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.(en)
*Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.(en)
*This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.(en)
*This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.(en)
*This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.(en)
*This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.(en)
*Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.(en)

*Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.(en)
*The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.(en)
*The status of the pathology test result as a whole.(en)
*The test was aborted and never completed.(en)
*The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.(en)
*Actual value of the result. Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts, free text, or multimedia images.(en)
*Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.(en)

*A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.(en)

*Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.(en)
*Details about the individual specimen to which these Result group test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.(en)
*Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.(en)
*The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Overall test result status.(en)
*Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.(en)
*Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.(en)
*May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.(en)
*Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.(en)
*The date that the analysis was performed.(en)
*Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.(en)
*The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.(en)
*Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.(en)
*The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded Result status.(en)
*The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release(en)
*The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release(en)
Details about contact person within organisation
Name of a person to contact at the organisation.
*Name of a person to contact at the organisation.(en)
The specimen has been sent to the laboratory.
Some but not all technical results are available at the lab.
Some but not all clinical results are available at the lab.
The results have been validated by the requesting clinician.
The specimen has been received and processing has been scheduled.
Identifier of the specimen collection appointment.
Order message has been sent to lab.
Transport of the specimen to the laboratory has been scheduled.
The test was aborted by the laboratory.
Actions arising based on a laboratory request
Actions arising from a laboratory specimen request.
The lab request has been postponed but will be organised in the future
An appointment for the specimen collection has been arranged
The speciment for this lab request has been collected
The specimen of this lab request has been sent out or received by the laboratory
All tests has been completed at the lab, but not clinically reported.
The laboratory action related to the laboratory request is completed and report processed
All test results have been clinically reported at the lab.
The investigator has established that further laboratory request is required
The person did not attend for their appointment
The lab test has not been implemented, but no further contact with the laboratory
The person did not attend on multiple occasions - no further appointments will been sent
Lab test has been aborted because of inappropriate specimen
The name of the test that was ordered.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The identifier of the person placing the request.
The identifier of the organisation to whom the request has been made.
*The specimen has been sent to the laboratory.(en)
*Some but not all technical results are available at the lab.(en)
*Some but not all clinical results are available at the lab.(en)
*The results have been validated by the requesting clinician.(en)
*The specimen has been received and processing has been scheduled.(en)
*Order message has been sent to lab.(en)
*Transport of the specimen to the laboratory has been scheduled.(en)
*The test was aborted by the laboratory.(en)
*Actions arising based on a laboratory request(en)
*Actions arising from a laboratory specimen request.(en)
*The lab request has been postponed but will be organised in the future(en)
*An appointment for the specimen collection has been arranged(en)
*The speciment for this lab request has been collected(en)
*The specimen of this lab request has been sent out or received by the laboratory(en)
*All tests has been completed at the lab, but not clinically reported.(en)
*The laboratory action related to the laboratory request is completed and report processed(en)
*All test results have been clinically reported at the lab.(en)
*The investigator has established that further laboratory request is required(en)
*The person did not attend for their appointment(en)
*The lab test has not been implemented, but no further contact with the laboratory(en)
*The person did not attend on multiple occasions - no further appointments will been sent(en)
*Lab test has been aborted because of inappropriate specimen(en)
*The name of the test that was ordered.(en)
*The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.(en)
*The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.(en)
*The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.(en)
*The identifier of the person placing the request.(en)
*The identifier of the organisation to whom the request has been made.(en)
Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.

ID asa zdravljenja, ki mu pripada ta composition. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.(en)
ID asa zdravljenja na oddelku, ki mu pripada ta composition.
ID portleta v katerem so shranjene informacije o shranjenom composition-u.
